title: 103_s394
content: Credit for payments or contributions to certain cooperative research organizations. The amendment allows for a 50 percent credit on qualified cooperative research expenditures. Qualified contributions to research consortia for qualified research are defined as qualified cooperative research expenditures. The term 'qualified cooperative research expenditures' refers to contributions to research consortia for qualified research. Contributions are subject to limitations based on private source funding ratios. The private source funding ratio for taxpayer contributions to research consortia is calculated based on the organization's gross receipts over the past two taxable years. The private source funding ratio for taxpayer contributions to research consortia is calculated based on the organization's gross receipts over the past three taxable years. Limitations include not taking into account contributions representing costs allocated to services exceeding cash contributions or overhead exceeding 25% of salary and benefits for services. The private source funding ratio for taxpayer contributions to research consortia is calculated based on the organization's gross receipts over the past three taxable years. Limitations include contributions to a qualified cooperative research consortium exceeding one-third of the consortium's total nongovernmental support for the taxable year. If a consortium has fewer than 5 participants, each person's qualified contributions will be reduced. If a qualified cooperative research consortium has less than 5 persons making nongovernmental contributions, the qualified contributions of each person will be reduced by 20% if there are 4 persons, or by 40% if there are 3 persons. A qualified cooperative research consortium is an organization registered under the National Cooperative Research Act of 1984 with at least 5 contributors during the taxable year. The registration requirement for a qualified cooperative research consortium under the National Cooperative Research Act of 1984 states that the organization must have at least 5 contributors during the taxable year, with specific contribution limits for members to qualify. The National Cooperative Research Act of 1984 requires a qualified cooperative research consortium to have at least 5 contributors, with contribution limits to qualify. Contributions must not exceed 50% from a single member or 85% from two members in the same trade or business. Noncash contributions are valued at cost, and overhead for services provided by employees is included. Double benefits are not allowed in computing qualified cooperative research. The National Cooperative Research Act of 1984 sets requirements for qualified cooperative research consortia, including contribution limits and valuation of noncash contributions. Overhead for services provided by employees must be included, and double benefits are not allowed in computing qualified cooperative research expenditures. Additionally, prepaid contributions to qualified research consortia are treated as paid or incurred during the period in which the research is conducted. Consortia must provide reports to the Secretary with specific information as required. Each qualified cooperative research consortium must submit a report to the Secretary, including certification, private funding ratio, and other required information. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after the enactment date of this Act.
